|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|beautify|HookyQR|1.0.2|
|project-manager|alefragnani|0.13.5|
|theme-desertex|casualjim|0.0.6|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.8|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.2.0|

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Go to any line of code, I usually insert Emoji in the HTML code or console.log in Javascript
2. Press Ctrl+Cmd+Space to open the Dialog to select Emoji
3. Navigate between Emoji by arrow buttons, press Enter to choose. Sometimes it will break the code, insert more space or comma character, sometimes it just insert exactly that Emoji

data.title: RFC: Add git task queue for better git workflow
data.body:
## Introduction
The current git support lack of task queue. for a daily use example

```bash
git add changes.log
git commit -am "some log"
git push ci master
git push origin master
git push pub master
```

## Proposal

We may add a git task queue list , once click git command on the ui, just put it into a queue, an example queue may like 

```bash
[] git add changes.log
[] git commit -am "some log"
[] git push ci master
[] git push origin master
[] git push pub master
```

and there can be status change after the queue processed one by one
```bash
[Done] git add changes.log
[Working] git commit -am "some log"
[Error] git push ci master
[Cancelled] git push origin master
[Pending] git push pub master
```

The task in the queue can have serval status

* Done: the task execute success
* Error: There be error when execute the task
* Cancelled: The task been cancelled
* Working: The task been executed
* Pending: The task waiting for execute

data.title: Auto detect encoding from HTML charset attribute
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.10.2 (8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331, 2017-03-08T13:56:35.908Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|beautify|HookyQR|1.0.2|
|html-snippets|abusaidm|0.1.0|
|polymer-snippets|chimon2000|1.0.1|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.8|
|vscode-dash|deerawan|1.4.0|
|vscode-babel-coloring|dzannotti|0.0.4|
|rest-client|humao|0.13.0|
|language-polymer|jonwolfe|0.8.4|
|prettify-json|mohsen1|0.0.3|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.10.5|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.7.0|
|polymer-ide|polymer|0.4.3|
|java|redhat|0.0.13|
|elm|sbrink|0.8.3|
|arduino-vscode|steveyin|0.2.2|
|JavaScriptSnippets|xabikos|1.4.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. get html file with non-utf8 encoding and also meta tag in it
for example
```html
<!doctype html>
<html lang="ko">
<head>
	<meta charset="euc-kr" />
...
```
assume above file is encoded with `euc-kr` encoding. 
2. set `files.encoding` option as `utf8`
3. open that file and it is opened as `utf8`. `euc-kr` character parts in file are not rendered correctly.

my suggestion is, when html file have `<meta charset="..."/>`, how about vscode to attempt to open that file with specified charset?
or auto detect by somehow?
or.. `files.encoding` option might be an array and order is precedence. if attempt to `utf8` decoding fails or produce screwed character, try next one.
```json
"files.encoding" : ["utf8", "euc-kr"]
```

[sample.html.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/866666/sample.html.zip)

I attach sample `euc-kr` file as above.

data.title: Send machineId in crash reports
Test: Terminal Shell Selection on Windows
data.body:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/22260

- [x] Windows - @alexandrudima 

To make the integrated terminal on Windows more usable, a popup will now appear informing the user that the shell can be changed. Please test the following:

- cmd, powershell, git bash and wsl bash (Windows Insiders only) are detected appropriately
- The popup will only appear under the following circumstances:
  - OS is Windows
  - The terminal was launched via an explicit "open terminal" user action (ie. toggle panel, focus terminal, create new terminal). It should not happen on panel restore after relaunch, debug opening a terminal, tasks opening a terminal
  - The `terminal.integrated.neverSuggestSelectWindowsShell` local storage key is not `true` (this is set when "OK, Never Show Again" is selected
  - The current configured shell is the default

The local storage key `terminal.integrated.neverSuggestSelectWindowsShell` can be changed/deleted from the Application tab in dev tools.

data.title: Test: Terminal link improvements
data.body:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/21226, https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/21506

- [x] Windows - @michelkaporin 
- [x] macOS - @mousetraps 
- [x] Linux - @ramya-rao-a 

Terminal links have had the following improvements made:

- Links are validated, all links should now do something
- The hover experience now mimics the editor, ctrl/cmd is required to trigger the link and a tooltip will appear as a hint
- `[` and `]` are no longer allowed in local links

data.title: Test: Custom workspace terminal shells
data.body:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/19758

- [x] Windows - @dbaeumer 
- [x] macOS or Linux - @chrmarti 

Users can once again specify terminal shells in workspace settings. It now presents a message when you launch a terminal asking to whitelist, blacklist or ignore the workspace, while opening the default shell in the meantime.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/24275889/2184f602-0ff0-11e7-8828-f2a6c41d90f2.png)

Please test that all the options work as expected, the setting itself is saved in the workspace's local storage using key `terminal.integrated.isWorkspaceShellAllowed`, you can change/delete it in the Application tab of dev tools.

data.title: Filetype associations don't affect explorer icons
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set files.associations to include .mak and .Mak files as makefiles
2. Set workbench.iconTheme to "vs-seti"
3. Open a folder containing a make file with a name of the form *.mak (e.g., qswlib.mak)
4. Observe that the generic plain text icon is shown, rather than the "M" makefile icon.

So, in my settings.json I have (among other settings):

    "files.associations": {
        "*.mak": "makefile",
        "makefile": "makefile",
        "Makefile": "makefile",
        "*.Mak": "makefile"
    },
    "[makefile]": {
          "editor.insertSpaces": false
    },
    "workbench.iconTheme": "vs-seti"

In my current open folder (or directories within that folder) I have several makefiles.

One named "makefile" is correctly detected as a makefile (as shown by the "Makefile" in the status bar), and shows the "M" icon. Tabs are inserted, as expected:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6267121/24274048/ea3e0964-0ff3-11e7-9146-8638f38cd34c.png)


Another, named "qswlib.mak" is also correctly detected as a makefile (as shown by the "Makefile" in the status bar) and tabs are correctly inserted, but the "M" icon is not displayed:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6267121/24274038/dbae0822-0ff3-11e7-898b-93b2277b1b67.png)

data.title: Extensions: Query UI State
data.body:
Extensions need to be able to query the UI State. Is the sidebar open, which viewlet is visible, are there multiple editor columns, in the bottom section is the terminal, output, or problem viewer active, etc.

For example, I have a small [Auto-Collapse Explorer](https://github.com/hoovercj/vscode-api-playground/tree/master/AutoCollapseExplorer) extension that I'd like to publish that needs this functionality.

When the active editor changes, the extension collapses the explorer and then focuses the active editor.

This should only happen if:
* There is an active editor (already possible to check)
* The sidebar is open (not currently possible)
* The explorer widget is open in the sidebar (not currently possible)

As the sidebar opens up to more viewlets (different SCM views, extension provided viewlets, etc.) this will become even more useful to extension developers.

data.title: Mitigate #22900. Use setInterval instead of animation for flat blinking on mac/linux
data.body:
The CPU usage on Mac and Linux are not reasonable with blinking cursor due to https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=361587 so here we replace the animation with intervals. Windows looks good always.

This PR starts with flat blinking style. Other blinking styles (smooth, phase) are using `ease-in-out` step function and I'm worried about the perf of simulating `ease-in-out ` in JavaScript. To make `ease-in-out ` smooth, we need to make Interval as small as possible but making it small means updating `opacity` more often.

data.title: Disable Implementations Code lens For TS < 2.2.1
data.body: The results of `implementations` from TSServer is not reliable in versions of TS prior to 2.2.1. We should disable the implementations code lens in those cases as well, just like we disable the `go to implementation` provider

data.title: Terminal doesn't send onExit event if terminal is not visible
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: master
- OS: Windows (not sure if this happens on other OSes)

Steps:
- tasks.json file
```json
{
	// See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
	// for the documentation about the tasks.json format
	"version": "2.0.0",
	"command": "tsc",
	"isShellCommand": true,
	"args": ["-p", "."],
	"showOutput": "silent",
	"echoCommand": true,
	"problemMatcher": "$tsc"
}
```
- have tsc installed globally
- tsconfig.json file
```json
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "target": "es5",
        "module": "commonjs",
        "sourceMap": true
    }
}
```
- HelloWorld.ts
```ts
class Startup {
    public static main(): number {
        console.log('Hello World');
        return 0;
    }
}

Startup.main();
```
- close bottom panel so that the terminal is not visible
- reload the window
- run the task by pressing Ctrl+Shift+B

Observe: the task spinner goes forever

- open the terminal

Observe: the task is terminated. But you can't press a key to close it. Even killing it will not send an exit event.
- reload Window
- bring terminal to front
- Ctrl+Shift+B

Observe: everything works as expected.

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open Window A in a project without `.vscode` directory.
2. Open Window B in a project with `.vscode` containing language-specific `settings.json`
3. Window A will take on those settings in Window B's `.vscode` as user settings.

data.title: Provide a way to control debugger stop focus changes

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VS Code 1.10.2
- Windows 10 Anniversary

In the latest update of the PowerShell extension (0.11.0) we now use an integrated terminal instead of the Debug Console for interactive execution of commands.  PowerShell allows the user to type commands in the console to initiate debugger operations like "stepInto", "stepOut" and "continue".  When the user types such a command and presses "Enter", the focus jumps back up to the editor pane when the debugger stops at the next line or breakpoint.

I would really appreciate a way to tell the debugger client UI to not change the focus automatically so that the user can keep typing commands into the console without having to manually set focus back there.

Thanks!

data.title: Windows-specific: OS shortcuts to launch new instance not working
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.10.2 (8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331, 2017-03-08T14:02:52.799Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|cake-vscode|cake-build|0.6.0|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.6.2|
|code-settings-sync|Shan|2.4.3|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch Visual Studio Code on Windows
2. With it running in the Windows Task Bar, Shift+Click the icon to launch a new instance (Additionally, Win+Shift+{# index in Task Bar})

Expected:

I was hoping it would start a new VS Code window/instance (similar to how it works for VS2017, Explorer, Chrome, Notepad, etc.)

Actual:

Gives focus to previously launched VS Code instance

Workaround:

Once previous instance is given focus, you can Ctrl+Shift+N to do what the Windows shortcut would normally do.

data.title: Provide command line switch that specifies a path to custom settings.json file
data.body:
I now use VSCode in a number of different ways and will be opening new instances of VSCode through different methods. Would be nice if it was possible to pass to the code.exe command a parameter that specifies a path to a custom settings.json file that could be used for these different methods to override the default user settings.json file.

For instance, I utilize the PowerShell extension a lot. Most of the time I will want the PowerShell extension to load the PowerShell session it uses to handle IntelliSense, code navigation, integrated console, etc. For me this takes a considerable amount of time as my profile must connect to Active Directory, Exchange, Lync, etc. in order to load modules for the services I develop for. This is perfectly fine when I am about to work on some project where I need all of those remote PowerShell sessions loaded. However, ever since VSCode started getting much faster start up times I have also started using VSCode to quickly view PowerShell files using the context menu in Windows Explorer. I just right click a file and say "Open in VSCode". However, loading all these remote sessions just to quickly view a file is problematic for a number of reasons.

The PowerShell extension now provides a setting, `"powershell.startAutomatically": true`. Now I can set that setting to false to prevent the automatic loading of these session and I can also manually start it on demand with the `PowerShell: Restart Current Session` command. However, it would be nice if I could just have a separate settings.json file that has it disabled and then point the registry for the VSCode context menu to use this separate settings.json file via a command line switch. 

I realize this use case is fairly unique but I could imagine providing such a command line switch would be useful in a number of other circumstances.
